comments.commentBody: Hey Knicks Fans. The Denver Nuggets came to town and allowerd Wilson Chandler to show his versatile game. At BBALLBREAKDOWN, we show you the insights from a coach's perspective of this game - including many highlights of Chandler, Stoudemire, Fields, and Felton. http://youtube.com/bballbreakdown

As much as I cringe each time Duchene records a point, I have a feeling he would have about 15 points this season if he were on the Islanders.  That said, I'm severely disappointed so far with John Tavares.  The Isles could have used Duchene's speed.

I am a long-time, die-hard Islanders fan. I feel really sorry for Tavares and some of the Isles' other strong young players. Management has turned this team into a joke, and are hampering the ability of a potential star player like Tavares to develop. It's sad.

CB,
Can you parlay work for such a reputable outlet like the Times into a re-instatement of your credentials. If you were actually under the employ of the print version, could they still deny you access? Do a good job and hopefully they will hire you. Do it for cheap so we can get our coverage back!
As an Islanders fan, this just makes me sad.  Hopefully they'll get this thing turned around.  Nice work as always CB.
Great piece.  It certainly helps Duchene that he's surrounded by more high end talent than Tavares.
Would love to see John Tavares' numbers surrounded by some bona fide NHL talent as opposed to the AHL squad he currently plays with.

Long term when the Islanders get the correct players for Tavares, he will end up leading Duchene to hopefully the hall of fame for both players. It all falls upon on  the management of Mr. Wang and Mr. Snow.
2 talented players in 2 very different scenarios, stick either in the others position and i bet there numbers are the same
Bobby ryan should have handed koivu his stick back right after the goal
loudest the coliseums been all season
Ellis had his pads handed to him, of course he's going to complain. Nice that Edmonton fans finally had something to feel good about.

Always take the better all around athlete and Matt Duchene was that choice, however,10,000 fans would have walked out of the 2009 draft party if any name other than John Tavares'  was called, so we have no one to blame but ourselves.

I think it's important to note how truly terrible the rest of The Islanders team is. P.A. Parenteau, Bruno Gervais, John Sim, Milan Jurcina, Mark Eaton, and several others would be fortunate to be competing for a job on almost any other team in the league.

The Islanders are fielding what amounts to a minor league team because the owner didn't get an arena. Colorado appears to be a healthy, thriving franchise. For Tavares' good, let's hope one day he plays for a less dismal organization.

Duchene would be a better fit on the Isles now only because the team is incredibly slow as it stands, and he has some wheels.  But as (if) the Isles get some faster forwards into the lineup, Tavares' instincts around the net will pay off big time.  John Tavares is the only thing Islanders that I am not concerned about.  Great instincts, excellent work ethic, and a history of showing up in big games.  He'll be an excellent Islander for years to come so long as he doesn't demand a trade out of here because of the way things are going.

Does his suggestion include prohibitions against sex amongst gay soccer players as well, or just gay fans, or are we foolish enough to think that none of those boys in shorts chasing after one another and a ball are gay?
Super futboler, a proven embassador, and a dedicated humanitarian.

Stanford update: I met with Paul Mitiguy and Apoorva Rajagopal yesterday for several hours and ran various simulations. The simulation software was something Paul had developed and includes material compressibility etc. The results seem to validate our Numberplay conversation as well as my recent experiments. Some of the findings.

1. if small gaps are present final velocities are 1/81, 4/81, etc. (Hans)
2. if no gaps are present and compressibility isn't included then the final velocities are indeterminate. the balls actually fly all over the place unpredictably. *tiny* differences in ball diameter or string length or ball spacing suddenly made everything predictable. (Ravi)
3. Balls tended to clump into groups of two. Giovanni noticed this in the video. This happened regardless of how many balls of mass m were used (we tried with 2, 3, 4 and 5 balls). Apoorva noticed this at Stanford and wondered if perhaps the balls would group into sets of three if the 1st ball were mass 3m.
4. At the very end of our session together Paul modeled the interaction as a ball hitting a series of four springs. The result closely matched that seen in experiments (and Pradeep's calculation): the last mass (spring) velocity was considerably greater than that of the first four masses, which had similar near-zero velocities. The springs in this analysis were also grouped into sets of two: the first and second ended up adjacent as did the third and forth.

At this point we stopped.

Ian...what is the simple research? I think the vast majority of people on here are knowledgable but I have yet to see a clear answer as to why he was only involved briefly. If we didn't play him because he was not yet fit then why did we bring him?

Michael Bradley tries. He actually played well at the WC. What I find distasteful is that he is guaranteed a spot whether he plays well or not. He is never subbed out and he is not THAT good to be untouchable. Holden has a higher ceiling than MB. I'll be curious as what teams they are on in 2 years

#23

American officials saying Iraq to have WMD does not mean every time they say something is a lie.

I can't understand how you think this reasoning is not absurd.

Its not so much the nuclear bombs that are a threat unless these countries with them come under attack then of course they would use them. The bigger threat is the recent WikiLeaks release of documents showing U.S. Sec. of State sent out orders that she be provided with the ten most sensitive sites to survial of U.S. and now this information has been published and some of these sites are not even in the U.S. such as a medical lab somewhere in Europe making medications to fight things like smallpox which is deadly and spreads rapidly.  Israel has nuclear weapons and who says they want use them if under serious attack?

@#12 Richard in Denver....Fear! Fear! Fear! And why not? It worked for Republicans before.

No one has forgotten Pearl Harbor. But you've seem to have forgotten why the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. They wanted an Asian Empire and they wanted to neutralize our Pacific Fleet which was a threat to their plans of Empire. The North Koreans regime is not looking to take over Asia. Your analogy is wanting.
Uh oh, don't tell me North Korea has WMDs!

It might be time to think about standing back and letting South Korea go nuclear itself. Why not? They're a wealthy democracy, being threatened by a nuclear-armed basket-case regime. They have the technology and even the material. And if nothing else, the prospect of a nuclear-armed South Korea might yank China down off the fence--fast.

Its already too late to contain it. Too bad for all the North Koreans that must suffer under this maniacal regime. The USA failed both them and ourselves in containing another nuclear power. How could we let so many join the ranks of nuclear weapons??
